Award.AwardTitle: Particle and Quantum Field Theory Investigations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors G. Gabadadze, M. Porrati, and A. Sirlin at New York University.

Members of this research group work towards solving fundamental questions in elementary particle physics, cosmology, and gravitation. The research interests of these faculty members are complementary to one another. To discover new physics it is essential to master the theory that describes all known elementary interactions excluding gravity, namely the so-called Standard Model. This is the aim of Prof. Sirlin's research. Quantum gravity and supergravity are the focus of Prof. Porrati's research. These are the theories most relevant in the study of the universe as a whole, i.e. at very large distances, or for understanding the very early universe. The study of quantum gravity also connects with attempts to understand the nature of dark matter and dark energy --- mysterious forms of matter and energy which are critical for understanding the way in which the universe evolves. These problems are investigated by Profs. Porrati and Gabadadze. Thus, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. Broader impacts are also expected from the project. All senior investigators carry out their research in close collaboration with graduate students and postdocs, who are thus trained in advanced theoretical research. Dissemination of research results will occur through review articles to be published in specialized and popular-science journals as well as through the organization of workshops, video- and Internet-based courses, and popular lectures.

More specifically, Porrati plans to study topology-changing transition amplitudes in pure AdS3 gravity as well as the torus partition function and certain indices for pure 3D gravity and supergravity in various formulations. He also plans to study a generalization of matter couplings in certain supergravity models of inflation containing higher powers of the scalar curvature. Properties of high-spin particles in interaction in AdS and Minkowski backgrounds will be studied by Porrati continuing work done in the last years. Porrati also plans to study holographic renormalization flows of 2D conformal field theories with different left and right central charges, using a recently discovered new theory of AdS3 massive gravity called "minimal massive gravity." Gabadadze is proposing research in several different directions --- on the cosmological constant problem and modified gravity, on the AdS/CFT correspondence for massive gravity, on quantum liquids in dwarf stars, and on solitons in cold atom systems --- all using the method of effective quantum field theory as a unifying theme. Finally, in view of the increased precision of a 2013 measurement reported by the MuCap Collaboration, Sirlin plans to update and improve his 2007 analysis. In particular, he plans to study the possibility that further improvement in the experimental precision may lead to an independent, accurate value for the axial-vector coupling $g_{A}$, a result that may have important implications for neutron beta decay. Sirlin also plans to study the radiative corrections to antineutrino capture by protons, a process that is currently important for reactor studies of neutrino oscillations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research supported by the grant covered a broad spectrum of fundamental topics in theoretical physics. It gave irreplaceable and unique training in research to students and postdoctorals and obtained results of relevance to theoretical physicists, experimental high energy physicists and cosmologists alike.

Gababadze, jointly with a graduate student, S. Yu, developed a novel approach to the problem based on nonlocal field theories. The approach enables one to turn the cosmological constant  -- no matter how large --  into a parameter that is not observable in our universe. The latter is a desirable feature since the cosmological constant receives contributions from many different scales of particle physics, each contribution exceeding by many orders of magnitude the value that could have been consistent with the observations.  In this new approach the modifications of the conventional local theory are significant only for the cosmological constant -- a source of energy and momentum that is not localized in space and does not dilute in time. All the other localized and/or time dependent sources -- no matter how slow the time dependence -- are unaffected. The observed cosmic acceleration in this approach can't be due to a small cosmological constant, and should be described by other mechanisms known in the literature. Gabadadze studies various cosmological scenarios in this approach and some of the observational consequences that may rule out this proposal.     
                                      

Porrati and collaborators found that many important physical quantities in a string theory living on a special high-curvature space-time in three dimensions are captured exactly by a totally different theory: a non-gravitational theory in two dimensions. If the curvature of the space-time were any higher, black holes would cease to exist and dissolve into particles and strings.

Many recent studies of inflation in cosmology use "non-linear realizations" of supersymmetry. Porrati and collaborators found new non-linear realizations that, unlike known ones, exist only when gravity is dynamical.

Porrati and graduate student C.Y. Yu found new methods of computing important physical quantities --such as the free energy-- in a vast class of theories that can describe pure gravity in three space-time dimensions as well as the dynamics of fractional quantum Hall effect in condensed matter physics.

Quantum gravity in (asymptotically) flat space is still quite mysterious so the existence of infinitely-many conserved charges that can constrain the dynamics is particularly precious. Some of these charges were discovered in the 1960s and other ones only very recently. Porrati and collaborators have discoverd that these charges completely fix the dynamics of  zero-energy gravitons, independently of what the other gravitons and particles do. This property shows that they do not change the Hawking black hole radiation and is more generally relevant for the black hole information puzzle. Another important result was the discovery of how the recently discovered new charges act on gravitons and particles and that one of them is a topological invariant.

In Collaboration with R.J. Hill, P. Kammel, and W.J. Marciano, Sirlin reviewed the capture of muons by protons in muonic hydrogen (muH) as a probe of the nucleon structure predictions of Quantum Chromodynamics. Recent data were employed to update the induced pseudoscalar nucleon coupling derived from experiment. The result was found to agree with the updated theoretical prediction from chiral perturbation theory at the 8% level. If instead, the theoretical prediction for the pseudoscalar coupling was used as input, together with the independent neutrino scattering result, it lead to an improved determination of the charge radius, which is important for neutrino physics experiments.

Experimental studies of neutron decay show two anomalies: 1) a roughly 4 sigma difference between the average beam neutron lifetime and the average trapped ultracold neutron  determination ; 2) a 6 sigma discrepancy between the pre-2002 average axial-coupling and the post-2002 average. In collaboration with Czarnecki and Marciano, Sirlin correlated the neutron lifetime and axial-coupling values using a Standard Model relation. Consistency with that relation and better precision suggest the favored values for both quantities. A bound on exotic neutron beta decay branching ratios and its implications was also discussed.

The radiative corrections common to neutron and super-allowed nuclear beta decays were revisited by Sirlin, Czarnecki Marciano in light of a recent dispersion relation analysis  that found a result about 2.4 sigma larger than the previous 2006 evaluation.

In collaboration with Czarnecki and Marciano, Sirlin advocated a novel strategy for pion beta decay based on its role in determining ratios of the CKM (Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa) matrix elements, that determine quark flavor mixing, via a decay ratio that involves vector current processes. Employing a recent lattice result one also finds a value for the same ratio. These two determinations differ by 2.2 sigma. This  suggests a shift in the lattice value towards, input changes, or "new physics" effects.
